docs.title: Welcome to the GhostBSD Community Documentation
docs.text:
GhostBSD is a FreeBSD-based desktop operating system designed with simplicity, elegance, and user-friendliness in mind.

This documentation site serves as your central guide for understanding, installing, configuring, and mastering GhostBSD. Whether you're a beginner exploring BSD for the first time or a seasoned user customizing advanced features, this hub has you covered.

docs.title: 🧭 How to Navigate
docs.text:
All topics are organized using a structured SSID-style index inspired by U.S. Navy classification systems. You'll find sections grouped by categories such as:

  • Basic Orientation – Learn what GhostBSD is and how to install it
  • Desktop Environments – Explore MATE, XFCE, and desktop configuration
  • System Management – Use Software Station, Update Station, and tools
  • Networking & Hardware – Set up drivers, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and more
  • ZFS & Encryption – Manage your data with ZFS and native encryption
  • Development & Security – Write code, secure your system
  • Troubleshooting – Fix boot problems, audio issues, and more

Use the sidebar on the left to browse all categories.

docs.title: How to Set kern.cam.boot_delay=10000 in GhostBSD
docs.text: To give USB storage devices more time to initialize during boot, you can set kern.cam.boot_delay=10000 in GhostBSD. This introduces a 10-second delay for the CAM (Common Access Method) subsystem during device probing.

docs.title: Temporary Change (for current boot only)
docs.text:
1. Boot from the USB Drive Insert the GhostBSD USB and boot your system. Select the USB device from the BIOS/UEFI menu if needed.

  2. Interrupt the Boot Countdown When the bootloader screen appears (with a 10-second countdown), press any key (e.g., spacebar) to pause it.

  3. Enter the Loader Prompt Choose the option: 

    Escape to loader prompt
    Or press Esc / Shift+Esc. You should see:

OK
  1. Set the Boot Delay At the prompt, type:
set kern.cam.boot_delay=10000
  1. Continue Booting Then type:
boot

and press Enter.

Note: This setting is temporary and will reset after reboot.

docs.title: Make the Setting Permanent
docs.text:
To apply this setting persistently:

  1. Boot into a live GhostBSD session or another system that can access the USB.

  2. Open the following file with root permissions:

/boot/loader.conf
  1. Add this line:
kern.cam.boot_delay="10000"
  1. Save and reboot.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If the setting does not help or if you can’t access the loader prompt:

  • Recreate the USB using a verified ISO image.
  • Test the USB on another machine to rule out hardware issues.
  • Try other USB ports, especially rear-panel ones directly connected to the motherboard.

docs.title: Mounting External Drives
docs.text: This guide explains how to mount external drives, such as USB flash drives or external hard drives, in GhostBSD. It covers common filesystems including exFAT, NTFS, and UFS, using both graphical and terminal-based methods. GhostBSD provides user-friendly tools to make this process accessible for all users.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• An external drive (e.g., USB flash drive or external hard disk) formatted with exFAT, NTFS, UFS, or another filesystem.
  • A GhostBSD system with a desktop environment (e.g., MATE).
  • Basic user permissions (no root access required for GUI automounting; sudo required for terminal commands).
  • Required packages for specific filesystems (installed as needed, see Method 2).
  • The lsblk utility for identifying drives in the terminal (not installed by default):
  • Install lsblk by running: 
    sudo pkg install lsblk
  • This package is part of the sysutils/lsblk port and provides a user-friendly way to list block devices.

docs.title: Method 1: Automatic Mounting via Desktop Environment
docs.text:
GhostBSD’s desktop environments, such as MATE, often include automounting features for external drives.

  1. Connect the External Drive:
  2. Plug the external drive into a USB port.

  3. Wait a few seconds for the system to detect the drive.

  4. Check for Automount:

  5. If automounting is enabled, the drive should appear on the desktop or in the file manager (e.g., Caja for MATE).
  6. A notification may indicate the drive is mounted.

  7. Supported filesystems (e.g., exFAT, NTFS) typically automount if the necessary drivers are installed.

  8. Access the Drive:

  9. Double-click the drive icon on the desktop or locate it in the file manager.

  10. The drive is usually mounted under /media/username/ or /mnt/.

  11. Eject the Drive:

  12. Right-click the drive icon and select "Eject" or "Safely Remove."
  13. Wait for confirmation before unplugging the drive.

Note: If the drive does not automount, ensure automount settings are enabled in your desktop environment or proceed to Method 2. For exFAT or NTFS, you may need to install additional packages (see Method 2).

docs.title: Method 2: Manual Mounting via Terminal
docs.text:
Use the terminal for manual mounting, especially for filesystems like exFAT, NTFS, or UFS, or if automounting fails.

  1. Connect the External Drive:

  2. Plug the drive into a USB port.

  3. Identify the Drive:

  4. Ensure lsblk is installed (see Prerequisites). Run: 
    lsblk
  5. Identify your drive (e.g., /dev/da0s1 for a USB drive). Note the device name and partition.

  6. Alternatively, use dmesg | tail to see recent device detection messages.

  7. Create a Mount Point:

  8. Create a directory for mounting: 

    sudo mkdir /mnt/drive

  9. Mount the Drive:

  10. Use the appropriate command based on the filesystem type. Replace /dev/da0s1 with your drive’s device name.

### Mounting exFAT - Install exFAT Support (if not already installed): 

sudo pkg install exfat-utils fusefs-exfat
- Load the FUSE kernel module: 
sudo kldload fuse
- Mount the exFAT drive: 
sudo mount.exfat /dev/da0s1 /mnt/drive

### Mounting NTFS - Install NTFS Support (if not already installed): 

sudo pkg install ntfs-3g
- Mount the NTFS drive: 
sudo mount -t ntfs /dev/da0s1 /mnt/drive
- For read-write access with NTFS-3G: 
sudo ntfs-3g /dev/da0s1 /mnt/drive

### Mounting UFS - UFS (Unix File System) is native to BSD systems and typically does not require additional packages. - Mount the UFS drive: 

sudo mount -t ufs /dev/da0s1 /mnt/drive
- If the UFS volume is from a non-GhostBSD/FreeBSD system, specify the UFS version if needed: 
sudo mount -t ufs -o ufstype=ufs2 /dev/da0s1 /mnt/drive

  1. Access the Drive:

  2. Navigate to the mount point: 

    cd /mnt/drive
ls

  3. Unmount the Drive:

  4. Unmount the drive when done: 
    sudo umount /mnt/drive
  5. Remove the mount point if no longer needed: 
    sudo rmdir /mnt/drive

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Drive Not Detected:
  • Run dmesg to verify the system recognizes the drive: 
    dmesg | tail
  • Ensure the drive is properly connected and powered.
  • lsblk Not Found:
  • If lsblk is not installed, install it: 
    sudo pkg install lsblk
  • Alternatively, use camcontrol devlist to list devices: 
    camcontrol devlist
  • exFAT Mounting Fails:
  • Confirm the fuse kernel module is loaded: 
    kldstat | grep fuse
  • If not loaded, load it manually (sudo kldload fuse).
  • NTFS Permission Issues:
  • If the drive is read-only, use ntfs-3g for read-write access.
  • Adjust permissions if needed: 
    sudo chmod -R u+rw /mnt/drive
  • UFS Mounting Fails:
  • Check if the UFS version matches (e.g., UFS1 or UFS2). Use the -o ufstype=ufs2 option if necessary.
  • Ensure the drive is not corrupted by running: 
    sudo fsck_ufs /dev/da0s1
  • Missing Filesystem Support:
  • Install required packages for exFAT (exfat-utils, fusefs-exfat) or NTFS (ntfs-3g) as shown above.

docs.title: Additional Notes
docs.text:
• Filesystem Support:
  • exFAT requires exfat-utils and fusefs-exfat packages, which rely on FUSE.
  • NTFS requires ntfs-3g for full read-write support.
  • UFS is natively supported in GhostBSD, but cross-platform UFS volumes may require specific options.
  • Device Naming:
  • GhostBSD uses FreeBSD conventions (e.g., /dev/daX for USB drives, /dev/adaX for SATA drives).
  • Safety:
  • Always unmount drives before unplugging to prevent data loss.
  • Persistent Mounting:
  • For drives you frequently use, consider adding entries to /etc/fstab for automatic mounting. Example for an exFAT drive: 
    /dev/da0s1 /mnt/drive exfat rw 0 0
  • Consult the GhostBSD documentation for /etc/fstab configuration.
  • Performance:
  • exFAT and NTFS may have slower performance compared to UFS due to FUSE or compatibility layers.

Last Updated: April 2025
